content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, You are given a list of daily temperature data `temps` (numbers). Write a function `weather_data_analyzer` that performs statistical analyses on this data (use `Statistics` package). The function should return results in named tuple (construct it with `(; key1=value1,key2=value2)` syntax) containing the `average`, `max`, `min` temperatures, and a `trend` (can be only: `:increasing`, `:decreasing`, or `:stable`). If the list is empty, the function should return a named tuple with all values set to `nothing`.

Here is the function in Julia:

```julia
using Statistics

struct WeatherData
    average::Union{Float64, Nothing}
    max::Union{Float64, Nothing}
    min::Union{Float64, Nothing}
    trend::Union{Symbol, Nothing}
end

function weather_data_analyzer(temps)
    if isempty(temps)
        return WeatherData(nothing, nothing, nothing, nothing)
    end
    
    average = mean(temps)
    max = maximum(temps)
    min = minimum(temps)
    
    trend = if temps[1] < temps[end]
        :increasing
    elseif temps[1] > temps[end]
        :decreasing
    else
        :stable
    end
    
    return WeatherData(;average, max, min, trend)
end
```

To use it:

```julia
temps = [20.5, 21.3, 19.8, 20.0]

data = weather_data_analyzer(temps)
```

This returns a named tuple with the calculated values. If `temps` is empty, it will return all `nothing` values.
